title: Fix support for vector indices that require db client in composability framework
body:
### Motivation
Right now we cannot support any vector store indices that require a db client in our composability framework.

Main source of this issue is that we "lose" the db client when we construct a `ComposableGraph` from individual indices.
> This is because we don't store the full Index object, but instead we only grab the index struct and docstore objects

The proposed solution here is to store the db clients (from all children indices) in a `additional_query_context` field in `ComposableGraph`.
> A better solution is probably to store the full Index objects in the `ComposableGraph`, but this is a more involved change, so we defer to later.

### API changes
To load a composable graph with unserializable vector store clients, e.g.: 
```
# NOTE: only necessary if we passed in pinecone_index when constructing the vector store indexes
query_context_kwargs = {
    index.index_struct.index_id: {
        'vector_store': {
            'pinecone_index': pinecone_index, 
        }
    }
    for index in city_indices.values()
}

graph = ComposableGraph.load_from_disk("index_multi_doc_graph.json", query_context_kwargs=query_context_kwargs)
```

### Main changes 
* Add `query_context` as a property for `BaseGPTIndex`
> This allows subclasses to expose all index-specific state/services (beyond `index_struct` and index-agnostic `service_context`), and pass them to `ComposableGraph`  and `QueryRunner`.
> Currently, the main use-case of this is passing vector store objects. 
* Add `query_context` as a field for `ComposableGraph` and `QueryRunner` 
> This stores all `query_context` from child indices. So that it can be passed to the corresponding `Query` object at query time.

### Misc changes & cleanup
* Remove `GPTVectorStoreIndexQuery` subclasses
* Add save/load logic for VectorStore
> Add `from_dict` classmethod to reconstruct a VectorStore object from dict when possible. 
> We save VectorStore in both `GPTVectorStoreIndex` (keyed by "vector_store") and `ComposableGraph` (slightly differently, keyed by `additional_query_context` at the top level)
> Add `load_vector_store_from_dict` to support passing in additional kwargs (e.g. vector store client).  This allows users to pass in vector store client to load indices that we can't fully serialize.

title: Fix composability with vector stores that keeps text
body:
### Summary
* Fix composability with vector stores that keep text.
> The issue is that for vector stores that keep text, we directly reconstruct a node from the retrieved text and metadata, which means we "lose" our `IndexNode`s
> The solution is to add `IndexNode`s and `ImageNode`s to our document store, and then return the original node if the retrieve node doc_id is in the docstore.

### Misc changes
* Add a test for composing pinecone on pinecone
* Also split composability test files into 2, since it's getting too long.

title: load_from_disk resets llm_predictor
body:
Is it possible to modify `BaseGPTIndex.save_to_disk()` to also save `ServiceContext` or should it be saved/loaded separetly?

The issue is, once an index is saved, important configurations in ServiceContext will have to be reset upon loading the index. For example, users might use `gpt-3.5-turbo` as their LLMPredictor when they call `GPTSimpleVectorIndex.from_documents(docs, service_context=service_context)`, but then after saving and loading the index, they expect the same LLMPredictor to be set but this is not the case (it resets to default and more expensive davinci text model).

body:
Initially I thought the error was due to the loader not splitting chunks, but I'm still getting the mentioned error after adding a splitter. Maybe it's coming from OpenAI's API?

Bugfix branch: https://github.com/claysauruswrecks/llama-hub/tree/bugfix/github-repo-splitter

```
import pickle
import os
import logging
from llama_index import GPTSimpleVectorIndex

assert (
    os.getenv("OPENAI_API_KEY") is not None
), "Please set the OPENAI_API_KEY environment variable."

from llama_index import download_loader

logging.basicConfig(level=logging.DEBUG)

LLAMA_HUB_CONTENTS_URL = "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/claysauruswrecks/llama-hub/bugfix/github-repo-splitter"
LOADER_HUB_PATH = "/loader_hub"
LOADER_HUB_URL = LLAMA_HUB_CONTENTS_URL + LOADER_HUB_PATH

download_loader(
    "GithubRepositoryReader", loader_hub_url=LOADER_HUB_URL, refresh_cache=True
)

from llama_index.readers.llamahub_modules.github_repo import (
    GithubClient,
    GithubRepositoryReader,
)

docs = None

if os.path.exists("docs.pkl"):
    with open("docs.pkl", "rb") as f:
        docs = pickle.load(f)

if docs is None:
    github_client = GithubClient(os.getenv("GITHUB_TOKEN"))
    loader = GithubRepositoryReader(
        github_client,
        owner="jerryjliu",
        repo="llama_index",
        filter_directories=(
            ["gpt_index", "docs"],
            GithubRepositoryReader.FilterType.INCLUDE,
        ),
        filter_file_extensions=([".py"], GithubRepositoryReader.FilterType.INCLUDE),
        verbose=True,
        concurrent_requests=10,
    )

    docs = loader.load_data(commit_sha="1b739e1fcd525f73af4a7131dd52c7750e9ca247")

    with open("docs.pkl", "wb") as f:
        pickle.dump(docs, f)

index = GPTSimpleVectorIndex.from_documents(docs)

index.query("Explain each LlamaIndex class?")
```

title: GPTSimpleVectorIndex Throwing Error
body:
I'm experience the same issue with GPTSimpleVectorIndex that appeared in [issue 617](https://github.com/jerryjliu/llama_index/issues/617), but was not resolved. I tried the same simple test with the Paul Graham essay using a LLM from huggingface. 

Below is a minimum working example, note that if I use a list index instead of the simple vector index everything runs fine.

```{python}
from llama_index import GPTSimpleVectorIndex, SimpleDirectoryReader, PromptHelper, LLMPredictor, ServiceContext
import torch
from langchain.llms.base import LLM
from transformers import pipeline
from typing import Optional, List, Mapping, Any

# define prompt helper
# set maximum input size
max_input_size = 512
# set number of output tokens
num_output = 512
# set maximum chunk overlap
max_chunk_overlap = 20
prompt_helper = PromptHelper(max_input_size, num_output, max_chunk_overlap)


class CustomLLM(LLM):
    model_name = "t5-small"
    pipeline = pipeline("text2text-generation", model=model_name, device="cuda:0", model_kwargs={"torch_dtype":torch.bfloat16})

    def _call(self, prompt: str, stop: Optional[List[str]] = None) -> str:
        response = self.pipeline(prompt)[0]["generated_text"]

        # only return newly generated tokens
        return response

    @property
    def _identifying_params(self) -> Mapping[str, Any]:
        return {"name_of_model": self.model_name}

    @property
    def _llm_type(self) -> str:
        return "custom"

llm_predictor = LLMPredictor(llm=CustomLLM())

service_context = ServiceContext.from_defaults(llm_predictor=llm_predictor, prompt_helper=prompt_helper)


documents = SimpleDirectoryReader('data').load_data()
index = GPTSimpleVectorIndex.from_documents(documents, service_context=service_context)
```

title: Unable to specify schema in query to my postgres db table.
body:
I'm trying to do a query on one of my postgres db tables. I believe that the table is successfully fetched by sqlalchemy. But when I do an index.query() call on the table, I get the following error: 

```
sqlalchemy.exc.ProgrammingError: (psycopg2.errors.UndefinedTable) relation "market" does not exist
LINE 2: FROM Market 
             ^

[SQL: SELECT name, market_type, away_team_name, home_team_name 
FROM Market 
WHERE away_team_name = 'Wisconsin' OR home_team_name = 'Wisconsin' 
ORDER BY name;]
(Background on this error at: https://sqlalche.me/e/14/f405)
```


Code snippet: 

```
import os
os.environ["OPENAI_API_KEY"] = <key here>
from sqlalchemy import create_engine, Table, MetaData
from llama_index import SQLDatabase 
from llama_index.indices.struct_store import SQLContextContainerBuilder, GPTSQLStructStoreIndex


# Replace the values with your database credentials
user = 'postgres'
password = 'postgres'
host = 'localhost'
port = '54322'
database = 'postgres'

# Create a connection string to connect to the database
db_string = f'postgresql://postgres:postgres@localhost:54322/postgres'

# Create an engine to connect to the database
engine = create_engine(db_string)

# Create a metadata object to store table metadata
metadata = MetaData()

# Get the "Market" table object
market_table = Table('Market', metadata, schema="public", autoload=True, autoload_with=engine)

# Test the connection by executing a sample query
result = engine.execute('SELECT version()')
result_two = engine.execute('SET search_path to public')
print(result.fetchone())
print(market_table)

sql_database = SQLDatabase(engine, include_tables=['Market'])


market_text = (
    "This table gives information regarding markets for sports events.\n"
    "The user will query with codewords, where 'markets' corresponds to name and the name of the team\n"
    "corresponds to away_team_name or home_team_name."
)

table_context_dict={'Market': market_text}
context_builder = SQLContextContainerBuilder(sql_database, context_dict=table_context_dict)
context_container = context_builder.build_context_container()

# building the index
index = GPTSQLStructStoreIndex([], sql_database=sql_database, table=market_table)

query_str = "What are the markets for Wisconsin?"

# query the SQL index with the table context
response = index.query(query_str, sql_context_container=context_container)
print('Got this: ', response.extra_info['sql_query'])
print(response)

```

It seems like the query is unable to use the "public" schema. I've tried to make the query use that schema, but I am unable. The reason I think the error has to do with the schema is because the query says "FROM Market" rather than 'FROM public."Market"'. Does anyone have any pointers on how to resolve the problem?

title: Composing GPTSQLStructStoreIndex
body:
I haven't managed to directly use `ComposableGraph.from_indices` to compose several `GPTSQLStructStoreIndex` (each representing a single sql table). 
It seems querying the graph then requires to have the sql_database object & the table names. 

The [example here](https://github.com/jerryjliu/llama_index/blob/main/examples/struct_indices/SQLIndexDemo-ManyTables.ipynb) seems to refer to multiple tables, but I don't see them being added to an index anywhere. 

How would one compose several `GPTSQLStructStoreIndex` then? Representing either multiple tables in the same DB, or in multiple ones. Is composing several indices the right way?

body:
There’s a potential SQL injection / security issue. This code works in the example below.

```python
"a = 2\nb = int(input('your number: '))\nif b>a:\n    print('Yes!')"
```

```python
    db = SQLDatabase.from_uri(DATABASE_CONNECTION_STRING, include_tables=["auth_user", "student_courseenrollment", "course_overviews_courseoverview"])

    llm = OpenAI()

    _DEFAULT_TEMPLATE = """Given an input question, first create a syntactically correct {dialect} query to run, then look at the results of the query and return the answer.
    Use the following format:

    Question: "Question here"
    SQLQuery: "SQL Query to run"
    SQLResult: "Result of the SQLQuery"
    Answer: "Final answer here"

    Only use the following tables:

    {table_info}

    For example:
    If the input question is "How many students are in Introduction to Computer Science?"
    The SQLQuery would be "SELECT COUNT(DISTINCT user_id) FROM student_courseenrollment AS sc INNER JOIN course_overviews_courseoverview AS co ON sc.course_id = co.id WHERE co.display_name = 'Introduction to Computer Science' AND sc.is_active = 1;"

    If the input question is "How many students are in CS101?"
    The SQLQuery would be "SELECT COUNT(DISTINCT user_id) FROM student_courseenrollment AS sc INNER JOIN course_overviews_courseoverview AS co ON sc.course_id = co.id WHERE co.display_number_with_default = 'CS101' AND sc.is_active = 1;"

    if the input question is "How many students are?"
    The SQLQuery would be "SELECT COUNT(DISTINCT user_id) FROM student_courseenrollment AS sc INNER JOIN course_overviews_courseoverview AS co ON sc.course_id = co.id WHERE sc.is_active = 1;"

    if the input question is "When did the course CS101 start?"
    The SQLQuery would be "SELECT start FROM course_overviews_courseoverview WHERE display_number_with_default = 'CS101';"

    Question: {input}"""
    PROMPT = PromptTemplate(
        input_variables=["input", "table_info", "dialect"], template=_DEFAULT_TEMPLATE
    )

    db_chain = SQLDatabaseChain(llm=llm, database=db, prompt=PROMPT, verbose=True, return_intermediate_steps=True)
    result = db_chain(message)
```

Other than with prompts that filter pointed examples out, how should this be addressed?

title: Chroma client list.collections() loads a transformer for each collection
body:
when you have multiple collections in chroma and list them with list.collections() in the background each collection is loaded, and some default transformer is loaded for them too. This is a massive performance hit, and makes the the function unusable when you have more than one collection. 

It really shouldn't load any transformer for just listing the collections. Atleast the names are just in a simple collections table that can be queried with raw sql for the same list.

title: [0.5.0] Update composability API and associated notebooks and docs.
Batched Upserts to Pinecone
body:
Pinecone upserts are currently done via an upsert call for each embedding result. This is slower than batching upserts (which is recommended in: https://docs.pinecone.io/docs/insert-data).

As an example, for a set of 850 documents I have, batching upserts takes 6 seconds (whereas the current one-by-one upserting takes 50 seconds), so batching is much faster.

This change should lead to faster index construction/updating/adding for GPTPineconeIndex.

body:
before, the user could pass the llm_predictor as an arg through the graph.

The graph can be initialized with a service context, but users may still want to specify a separate service context during query-time. This is a convenience arg that would allow us to not modify existing notebooks too much.

Also reverted use_async back to False by default
